April 2025
County of Marin EMS C 0
ADULT CARDIAC ARREST
START CPR
CRITICAL INFORMATION
• Give O2 via BVM
• Attach monitor/defibrillator Witnessed vs Unwitnessed
• Apply defibrillator pads in Consider pre-cordial thump if
anterior/posterior position witnessed and defibrillator not
• IV/IO access immediately available
Compress at 100-120/min, 2”
depth with full recoil of chest
Yes No Use metronome or similar
Shockable Rhythm?
device
Mechanical CPR is mandatory
during transportation
Change compressors every
2 minutes
VF/pVT Asystole/PEA
Minimize interruptions
Defibrillate at 200J, 300J,
360J, or at manufacturer’s
recommendation
CPR 2 min • Epinephrine (0.1mg/ml) Do not stop compressions
1mg IV/IO while defibrillator is charging
• Repeat every 3-5min Resume compressions
• Max: 3 doses immediately after shock
Go to Policy: BLS Airway Management
• V-FIB/PULSELESS BLS airway preferred during
V-TACH, C 1 first 5 minutes
CPR 2 min
Use two-person BLS airway
management whenever
possible
Avoid excessive ventilation
30:2 compression/ventilation
Go to Policy:
ratio
• Asystole/PEA, C 2
ALS Airway Management
King Airway/i-gel/Video
laryngoscopy (VL)
Laryngoscopy for ETT must
occur with CPR in progress.
SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS Do not interrupt CPR for >10
seconds for tube placement
Transportation is warranted in the following situations: unsafe
Use continuous ETCO2 to
scene conditions, unstable airway, hypothermia/hyperthermia as
monitor CPR effectiveness and
primary cause of arrest
advanced airway placement
Consider transport of any patient pulled from a fire who does not
Maintain SpO2 94-99%
meet BLS Determination of Death or received Cyanokit
1 breath every 6 seconds
To assure ROSC continues, remain on scene for 5-10 minutes
and then transport to a STEMI Receiving Center
